questions.question_text: What are trophic levels? Give an example of a food chain and state the different trophic levels in it.
hints: Recall that trophic levels represent feeding positions in a food chain
Start with producers (plants), then primary consumers (herbivores), then secondary consumers (carnivores)
Example: Grass → Grasshopper → Frog → Snake

questions.question_text: What is the role of decomposers in the ecosystem?
hints: Think about what happens to dead organisms and waste
Decomposers break down complex organic matter
They recycle nutrients back into the soil

questions.question_text: Why are some substances biodegradable and some non-biodegradable?
hints: Consider the chemical structure of substances
Think about whether enzymes can break them down
Natural vs synthetic materials

questions.question_text: Give any two ways in which biodegradable substances would affect the environment.
hints: They can be broken down by microorganisms
They can cause foul smell if accumulated
They can be used as compost/manure

questions.question_text: Give any two ways in which non-biodegradable substances would affect the environment.
hints: They accumulate and cause pollution
They can harm animals if ingested
They take up landfill space for long periods

questions.question_text: What is ozone and how does it affect any ecosystem?
hints: Ozone is O3 molecule
It forms a protective layer in stratosphere
It blocks harmful UV radiation
UV radiation can damage living organisms

questions.question_text: How can you help in reducing the problem of waste disposal? Give any two methods.
hints: Practice segregation of biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste
Reduce, reuse, recycle
Use cloth bags instead of plastic
Compost kitchen waste

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups contain only biodegradable items? (a) Grass, flowers and leather (b) Grass, wood and plastic (c) Fruit-peels, cake and lime-juice (d) Cake, wood and grass
hints: Plastic is non-biodegradable
Leather is biodegradable as it comes from animals
All items in option (c) are organic and biodegradable

questions.question_text: Which of the following constitute a food-chain? (a) Grass, wheat and mango (b) Grass, goat and human (c) Goat, cow and elephant (d) Grass, fish and goat
hints: A food chain shows energy transfer from one organism to another
It must include producers and consumers
Option (b) shows grass (producer) → goat (primary consumer) → human (secondary consumer)

questions.question_text: Which of the following are environment-friendly practices? (a) Carrying cloth-bags to put purchases in while shopping (b) Switching off unnecessary lights and fans (c) Walking to school instead of getting your mother to drop you on her scooter (d) All of the above
hints: All options reduce environmental impact
Cloth bags reduce plastic waste
Switching off saves energy
Walking reduces pollution

questions.question_text: What will happen if we kill all the organisms in one trophic level?
hints: It will disrupt the food chain
The trophic level above will starve
The trophic level below may overpopulate
Ecosystem balance will be disturbed

questions.question_text: Will the impact of removing all the organisms in a trophic level be different for different trophic levels? Can the organisms of any trophic level be removed without causing any damage to the ecosystem?
hints: Removing producers affects entire ecosystem
Removing top predators may cause prey overpopulation
No trophic level can be removed without consequences
Each level has specific ecological role

questions.question_text: What is biological magnification? Will the levels of this magnification be different at different levels of the ecosystem?
hints: It's accumulation of non-biodegradable chemicals in food chain
Concentration increases at higher trophic levels
Top predators have highest concentration
Example: DDT in eagles

questions.question_text: What are the problems caused by the non-biodegradable wastes that we generate?
hints: They cause land pollution
They can choke drains and cause floods
Animals may eat them and die
They release toxic chemicals when burned

questions.question_text: If all the waste we generate is biodegradable, will this have no impact on the environment?
hints: Biodegradable waste can still cause problems
It can produce methane (greenhouse gas)
It can cause foul smell and attract pests
It requires proper management like composting

questions.question_text: Why is damage to the ozone layer a cause for concern? What steps are being taken to limit this damage?
hints: Ozone layer blocks harmful UV radiation
UV causes skin cancer, cataracts, damages plants
Montreal Protocol banned CFCs
CFC-free refrigerators are now mandatory
